stream_context.summary: Kaze begins production on Course 15 (Astral Arcade), a space/arcade-themed level built around 3D pinball-like traversal. He locks in a high-level layout (main hub area above, floating flipper/bumper pieces below) and starts modeling core interaction props (flipper, directional triangle bumper, launcher/trampoline, metal platforms). A major portion of the stream is spent iterating on how to visually communicate a “bumper ball” that pushes Mario back along his incoming direction in 3D, while also discussing legal limits around paid beta access and how outside commissioned work is constraining progress.
stream_context.significance_reason: Establishes Astral Arcade’s overall layout and ‘open-but-linear’ philosophy, begins modeling the level’s core traversal actors, and includes explicit legal reasoning about not selling beta access to the hack.

findings.summary: Astral Arcade now has a concrete plan, enabling Kaze to begin 3D modeling the level’s traversal pieces (flippers/bumpers/launchers).

The level layout is split into a main area (hub-like space arcade) and a lower zone filled with floating pinball/flipper elements; the lower zone acts as a traversal playground that can launch the player back into the main area.
Kaze’s intended macro-feel for Astral Arcade is “Mario Galaxy-like”: it should feel open while still being linear through intersecting, directed paths.
findings.quote: This level is gonna have a Mario Galaxy type design philosophy basically: feel open but be linear, which we do by having a bunch of random linear paths that somewhat intersect.

findings.summary: Planned pinball-inspired interactables include: flippers (force depends on landing position), directional triangle bumpers (shoot in facing direction), bumper balls (shoot you back the way you came), trampoline/button launch pads, and non-interactive/utility metal platform pieces.
Kaze is deliberately avoiding a single cohesive ‘full pinball machine’ layout; instead, Astral Arcade’s pinball parts will be disconnected floating chunks to better fit 3D traversal and exploration.
A key constraint is translating 2D pinball language into readable 3D: some 2D elements (e.g., speed-stripe lanes/tunnels) are hard to make legible in free space without walls/backdrops.

Kaze struggles to make a full spherical “bumper ball” read as something that repels the player in 3D; he tests multiple texture/shape approaches (beach-ball segmentation, triangle tessellation, glow, sprite/billboard decals) and concludes a full sphere may be impractical.
He considers switching the bumper from a full sphere to a half-sphere/hemisphere for readability and because it’s common in real pinball (implying it may be common because it works).

A promising bumper-ball visual solution emerges from chat reference imagery: a static core surrounded by a transparent outer shell (and possibly springs/bars), combined with squash/stretch or contraction when touched to sell ‘push-back’ behavior.
Kaze plans to rely on glow/emissive presentation for these actors (including making certain surfaces ‘light up’ and using contraction/expansion animation to telegraph launching).
Kaze refuses to distribute beta access through paid means (e.g., Patreon) because it could be construed as selling access to the ROM hack, which he believes would be legally risky.
findings.quote: I can’t give people access because if I did it via Patreon or something, I would basically be selling access to the game, which would be really bad legally speaking.

findings.summary: Progress on Return to Yoshi’s Island is temporarily slowed because Kaze has to finish an old commissioned project (another hack) that resurfaced after the commissioner sent money again, creating schedule pressure.
Kaze notes he’s been getting increasingly annoyed by YouTube comments lately, which is affecting his mood during development.
Kaze expects Biobak to iterate and improve early prop models later; Kaze is blocking out workable versions first to establish the set of pieces and their function.
findings.quote: I’m sure Biobak will improve this anyway, and for now…

biobak.summary: Kaze explicitly frames his current flipper model as a first pass that Biobak will likely refine/improve later, indicating a pipeline where Kaze prototypes and Biobak polishes visuals.
biobak.quote: I’m sure Biobak will improve this anyway.

findings.summary: Kaze mentions using textures that ‘Wise Guy’ sent him, suggesting ad-hoc asset support from community contacts.
findings.quote: I have these textures—Wise Guy sent them to me.

findings.summary: A viewer-provided reference/image sparks the bumper redesign: Kaze shifts toward a transparent-shell + core concept and adds spring-like attachments to better communicate repulsion.

key_stories.title: Locking in the Astral Arcade layout and piece list
key_stories.summary: Kaze says Astral Arcade finally has a plan, allowing him to move from abstract brainstorming into concrete modeling of gameplay-critical parts. He outlines a two-layer structure: a main space hub above and a floating ‘pinball playground’ below that can shoot the player back upward.
key_stories.challenge: Without a defined level structure, modeling and programming individual pinball actors would be ungrounded and risk rework.
key_stories.process: He enumerates required pinball elements, filters them through ‘must work in 3D space,’ and decides the level should be made of disconnected floating components rather than a full pinball table.
key_stories.outcome: A clear blockout direction is established, and Kaze begins producing first-pass models for flippers, bumpers, and launcher pieces.

key_stories.title: The bumper ball readability problem in 3D
key_stories.summary: Kaze repeatedly fails to make a full spherical bumper read as a repelling object using simple textures and segmentation. He explores glow, billboard decals, and different texture patterns but remains unhappy with how it communicates function.
key_stories.challenge: A full sphere doesn’t visually imply ‘bounce away in the direction you came from’ the way classic 2D pinball bumpers do.
key_stories.process: He iterates through multiple visual motifs (beach ball slices, triangle tessellation, sprite-like overlays) and considers abandoning the full sphere for a half-sphere due to readability.
key_stories.outcome: He tentatively accepts that a hemisphere may be more practical, then pivots again after a viewer reference suggests a core + transparent shell approach that could preserve the ‘ball’ idea.
key_stories.key_quote: I think we should just take the L—it’s not gonna work out.

key_stories.title: Chat-driven breakthrough: core + transparent shell bumper concept
key_stories.summary: After a chat reference image, Kaze finds a new visual direction: a static core with a transparent outer shell that can contract/squash on contact, plus spring-like attachments. This aligns visuals with the intended physics response.
key_stories.challenge: Prior bumper designs looked ‘cool’ but failed the key readability test: players wouldn’t infer it pushes them away.
key_stories.process: He interprets the reference as a layered object (core + shell), then sketches/model-blocks how springs/bars might reinforce the ‘push’ metaphor and plans to animate contraction on touch.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze regains a ‘vision’ for the bumper and decides to proceed with this direction for implementation and later polish.
key_stories.key_quote: Now I have a good idea. I will implement that and then you guys will look at it and you will like it.

key_stories.title: Why paid beta access is off the table
key_stories.summary: Kaze answers a question about beta testing by jokingly demanding a ‘firstborn child,’ then clarifies the real constraint: he won’t provide access through paid systems like Patreon. He frames it as avoiding anything that looks like selling the hack.
key_stories.challenge: Community demand for early access conflicts with perceived Nintendo/legal risk in monetizing distribution.
key_stories.process: He explicitly reasons that paid access equals ‘selling the game,’ and rejects that route.
key_stories.outcome: Beta distribution remains limited/controlled, with monetized access avoided as a policy.
key_stories.key_quote: I would basically be selling access to the game, which would be really bad legally speaking.

key_stories.title: Outside commissioned work interrupts Return to Yoshi’s Island development
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains he has limited time for the hack because an old commission resurfaced: the commissioner sent money again, obligating him to finish it. He briefly shows the commissioned project, describing it as an edgy parody hack with multiple cities and crime/drug mechanics.
key_stories.challenge: Unexpected external obligations reduce available time and focus for Astral Arcade and the broader project.
key_stories.process: He prioritizes completing the commissioned work off-stream, acknowledging it will occupy the next few days.
key_stories.outcome: Return to Yoshi’s Island progress slows temporarily; stream work becomes smaller, incremental tasks.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions the main area will send you ‘all over the area with warps,’ contributing to an ‘open but linear’ structure, but he doesn’t detail how warps are surfaced to the player or how randomness is controlled.
questions: Are the warps deterministic, semi-random, or fully random? What controls where you end up?
How do you prevent the player from feeling lost if paths/warps are unpredictable?
What’s the intended ‘critical path’ through Astral Arcade versus optional detours?

open_questions.topic: Programming approach for flippers and bumpers
open_questions.context: Kaze states intended behaviors (flipper strength depends on landing point; triangle bumper shoots by facing; bumper ball returns you along incoming vector) and mentions he’s unsure how he’ll program contraction/animation yet.
questions: How will you compute the ‘incoming direction’ for the bumper ball in SM64’s physics (velocity, position delta, camera-relative)?
How will flipper impulse scale with contact point—distance from hinge, timing window, or surface normal?
Will contraction/expansion be purely visual or influence collision/impulse timing?

open_questions.topic: Final visual language for pinball parts
open_questions.context: Kaze wants all pieces to be visually coherent and likely emissive, but he postpones cohesion until all parts exist. He also debates sphere vs hemisphere and layered transparency solutions.
questions: What are the final art rules for Astral Arcade props (materials, glow colors, silhouette language)?
How do you ensure readability on real N64 hardware/limits (color banding, low-res textures, fog)?
Will Biobak define a unified style guide once prototypes are functional?

open_questions.context: Kaze notes classic ‘speed stripe’ lanes from 2D pinball may not work in free space without walls and backplates.
questions: Did you eventually find a 3D equivalent for speed lanes (tunnels, particle trails, transparent rails)?
How do you teach the player that an element is a ‘speed lane’ without a pinball table context?
Were any pinball mechanics cut specifically because they didn’t translate to 3D?

open_questions.topic: Course 15 scope and completion status of other courses
open_questions.context: Kaze answers that other courses are finished, implying Astral Arcade may be among the last major remaining levels, but the broader milestone context isn’t explained.
questions: What does ‘other courses are finished’ mean—blockout complete, art complete, or shippable complete?
Where does Astral Arcade sit in the project’s critical path toward release?
What remains after Astral Arcade: cutscenes, bosses, polish, optimization, QA?

open_questions.context: Kaze briefly says: “We want the CFL output, but we also need it to be linear,” without defining terms in-stream.
questions: What does ‘CFL output’ refer to in your level design vocabulary here?
How does that concept influence the geometry/warps/paths of Astral Arcade?
Is this tied to camera behavior, player flow metrics, or lighting/visual composition?

open_questions.context: Kaze indicates he will accept rough models now because Biobak can improve them later, implying a staged pipeline.
questions: How do you hand off assets between you and Biobak (Blender files, exports, naming conventions)?
What criteria determines ‘good enough to implement’ versus ‘needs polish before coding’?
Do you ever rework mechanics because art constraints changed (or vice versa)?

open_questions.topic: Legal risk strategy beyond beta access
open_questions.context: Kaze only comments on not selling access to the hack; broader legal strategy is not discussed.
questions: What other monetization/distribution rules do you follow to reduce Nintendo risk (no downloads, patch-only, no Patreon perks tied to builds)?
Have you consulted anyone (lawyer/peers) or learned from other projects’ takedowns?
How does legal caution shape public communication and release planning?

open_questions.topic: Impact of external commissioned work on the project timeline
open_questions.context: Kaze says an old commission resurfaced and will keep him busy, temporarily reducing progress on Return to Yoshi’s Island.
questions: How often do commissions interrupt development, and how do you decide whether to accept them?
Do you have a long-term schedule/budget plan to avoid context switching late in production?
Did this interruption change any milestones or force cuts?

open_questions.topic: N64 technical exploration teased (extra 1MB memory, cache)
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions two upcoming video ideas: unlocking an additional 1MB of usable N64 memory beyond the default 8MB, and a cache-related topic he calls ‘the best thing that ever happened to the N64,’ but doesn’t tie them directly to RTYI in this stream.
questions: Is the extra 1MB memory discovery being used for Return to Yoshi’s Island specifically (more textures, bigger levels, audio)?
What cache behavior/technique are you referring to, and does it benefit the hack’s performance?
Will these technical breakthroughs change any art/design constraints for late-game levels like Astral Arcade?
